pageData.text: Microbes and humans can inhabit the same areas. However, some microbes can be harmful to humans and may cause infections and diseases. Maintaining a level of hygiene is important for overall health. To combat the microbes, we use techniques to eliminate them. <button class='glossary-text'>Disinfectants</button> are designed to work with and on inanimate objects, whereas <button class='glossary-text'>antiseptics</button> work on or in living tissues. This investigation examines the effectiveness of commonly used disinfectants and antiseptics.

pageData.subTitle: Overview video: Evaluation of Antiseptics and Disinfectants

text: Differentiate between <button class='glossary-text'>disinfectants</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>antiseptics</button>, and sterilizing agents.
Describe factors that can affect the action of antimicrobial agents.
Determine the effective concentrations of specific disinfectants and antiseptics.

pageData.text: Although hospitals appear clean, in the U.S., it is estimated that hospital-acquired infections (HAI) are responsible for almost 3 million infections and 100,000 deaths a year. Data suggests that manual cleaning, disinfection, and <button class='glossary-text'>sterilization</button> are not sufficient to eliminate HAI<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>. Some institutions hope that UV-disinfection robots may help combat HAI.

UV-disinfection robots use ultraviolet light at a wavelength of 254 nm. This wavelength is bactericidal, sporicidal, fungicidal, and virucidal. The irradiation technique allows microbes to be killed with no mechanical removal of dirt or biological material, and protects healthcare workers from being exposed to pathogens in the rooms they are cleaning. Although there are limitations to UV-disinfection robots, there is great hope that this technology will become readily available for not only hospitals but also all public indoor spaces.

1Diab-El Schahawi, M., Zingg, W., Vos, M. et al. (2021). Ultraviolet disinfection robots to improve hospital cleaning: Real promise or just a gimmick? Antimicrob Resist Infect Control 10:33.
https://doi.org/10.1186/s13756-020-00878-4

pageData.desc: A UV robot within a plastic display case. The robot has a large opaque rectangular base with a display screen. Extending vertically from the base are several tall thin cylindrical bulbs.
pageData.altText: A UV robot within a plastic display case. The robot has a large opaque rectangular base with a display screen. Extending vertically from the base are several tall thin cylindrical bulbs.

pageData.text: Some microbes are harmful to human health. Limiting the number of environmental microbes that are in direct contact with humans will reduce the chance of infections. An example of this is Salmonella, a bacterium that is common in poultry and can cause food poisoning when consumed.

<button class='glossary-text'>Sterilization</button> is the removal or killing of all life—bacteria, viruses, fungi, protozoa, and so on—from a material or surface. Sterilizing agents include pressurized steam, certain harsh chemicals, and specific types of radiation. However, sterilization is not always necessary.

There are several methods to simply reduce the number of microbes in the environment. Substances that are used to reduce microbe levels on inanimate, nonliving surfaces or in liquids are called <button class='glossary-text'>disinfectants</button>. Most disinfectants are harmful to humans, either by touch or ingestion, and should not be used on or in living tissues. Substances that are used to reduce microbe levels on or in living tissues are called <button class='glossary-text'>antiseptics</button>. Even antiseptics may be too harsh to be used on a regular basis. For example, using a strong antiseptic on your skin several times a day can cause tissue damage. Both disinfectants and antiseptics may damage microbial cell membranes by destroying essential proteins or lipids and causing holes to appear. Essential cellular fluid, <button class='glossary-text'>cytoplasm</button>, will then exit the microbe and take proteins, amino acids, and other life-sustaining materials with it. Disinfectants and antiseptics can also alter the three-dimensional shapes of microbial proteins. This is known as <button class='glossary-text'>denaturing</button>. A protein’s three-dimensional shape is essential for its proper function, and a microbe will die without properly functioning proteins.

<button class='glossary-text'>Disinfectants</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>antiseptics</button> are effective in reducing the number of living microbes. However, some microbes are capable of entering a dormant stage, through a process called <button class='glossary-text'>sporulation</button>. In this stage called <button class='glossary-text'>dormancy</button> the microbes encapsulate themselves in structures that allow them to preserve their genetic material when environmental conditions are unfavorable. For example, a bacterial cell that has encapsulated itself and entered a dormant stage is called an <button class='glossary-text'>endospore</button> (Figure 1). Not all bacteria can form endospores, but those that do include the causative agents of anthrax, tetanus, and botulism. Microbes often go into dormancy when they encounter toxic environments, such as the addition of disinfectants or antiseptics. As soon as the environment is more favorable for the microbes, they will become active and start to reproduce again. Therefore, harsh <button class='glossary-text'>sterilization</button> methods are needed to eliminate the spores. An example is irradiation with ultraviolet C light (254 nm wavelength), which causes changes in the DNA of the microbe. This renders the microbe unable to manufacture essential proteins and cellular components. Another sterilization method is <button class='glossary-text'>autoclaving</button>, which uses pressured steam.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Many rod-shaped bacteria undergoing sporulation.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Many rod-shaped bacteria undergoing sporulation.

pageData.question: Which of the following is NOT a manner by which sterilization can kill microbes?

options.text: It disables protein production via DNA mutation.
It damages microbial cell membranes, causing cytoplasm leakage.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Sterilization involves disabling protein production or function or damaging cell membranes.

pageData.question: What is the function of an endospore?

options.text: to protect the dormant bacterium until environmental conditions are favorable
to nourish the new bacterium cell until it is large enough to find its own food
to shield the bacterium from the effects of irradiation
to serve as a food source for the dormant bacterium
to repair microbial membrane damage caused by a disinfectant

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: An endospore is a structure that allows bacteria to preserve their genetic material as they lie dormant when environmental conditions are unfavorable.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Both disinfectants and antiseptics may damage microbial cell membranes by destroying essential proteins or lipids and causing holes to appear. Disinfectants and antiseptics can also alter the three-dimensional shapes of microbial proteins. An example of harsh sterilization methods is irradiation with ultraviolet C light, which mutates the DNA of the microbe, rendering it unable to manufacture essential proteins and cellular components. However, microbes often go into dormancy when they encounter toxic environments, such as the addition of disinfectants or antiseptics. As soon as the environment is more favorable for the microbes, they will become active and start to reproduce again.

Disinfectants and antiseptics can also alter the three-dimensional shapes of microbial proteins. An example of harsh sterilization methods is irradiation with ultraviolet C light, which mutates the DNA of the microbe, rendering it unable to manufacture essential proteins and cellular components. However, microbes often go into dormancy when they encounter toxic environments, such as the addition of disinfectants or antiseptics. As soon as the environment is more favorable for the microbes, they will become active and start to reproduce again.

pageData.text: Several factors can influence the effectiveness of any of the microbial control methods described above, either on their own or in combination.

text: Type of microbe: Some microbes are more resilient than others, and a longer treatment time or higher concentration of antimicrobial chemical is needed to reduce their numbers.
Amount of microbes: When the number of microbes is high, there is a greater chance that one or more may survive and repopulate.
Antimicrobial chemical concentration: At low concentrations, the chance of at least one microbe surviving is higher than with higher concentrations.

Nature of the surface or material to be treated: Microbes can be partially protected from chemicals if they reside in cavities or pores on the surface. Furthermore, a smooth surface is easier to clean than an uneven surface. The surface itself can contain substances that may interfere or react with antimicrobial chemicals.

Temperature: When the temperature is lower, the metabolism of most microbes is slower. Therefore, lower amounts of chemicals are taken up by the microbes. Also, several bacterial species go into an -forming stage when the temperature becomes too low. As mentioned previously, endospores are able to withstand and .

pageData.text: In general, some common groups of chemicals are used as disinfectants and antiseptics.

text: Soaps and detergents are not very effective as antimicrobial agents but are mainly used to break the connection between microbes and surfaces. They are often used for <button class='glossary-text'>sanitizing</button>, reducing microbial numbers by cleaning.
Alcohols are very effective in breaking up membranes. They can also destroy the three-dimensional structures of proteins and make them ineffective. Alcohols will not destroy endospores.
Chlorine disrupts the three-dimensional structures of proteins and is mainly used in water. It is also used to sanitize food preparation surfaces.
Hydrogen peroxide is an oxidizing agent and works by producing free radicals, which disrupt membranes, DNA, and other cellular components.
Iodine, which is used as a disinfectant and antiseptic, also denatures proteins as an oxidizing agent.

pageData.text: There are several other methods of controlling microbes, but those mentioned are the most common ones used in a household or laboratory setting.

In this investigation, different concentrations of commonly used disinfectants (bleach and Lysol<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>) and antiseptics (hydrogen peroxide and isopropyl alcohol) will be used to determine their effectiveness in eliminating a common species of bacterium.

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. Before beginning the investigation, you will prepare your surface disinfectant, disposal jar and bacterial cultures. To begin, you will label your Petri dishes and prepare the disinfectant solutions in each dish. Then, you will prepare the control dish. Next, you will place filter paper in the E coli dry dish. Then, you will pour the E. coli broth into the E coli soak dish and add the glass beads. Next, you will transfer the beads from the E coli soak dish to the E coli dry dish and then place 1 bead in each solution dish. You will incubate the beads for 10 minutes and then transfer them to the labeled broth tubes. Once you have prepared all 13 tubes, you will incubate the tubes for 48 hours. Finally, you will check for bacterial growth and determine the effectiveness of each antiseptic.
pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. Before beginning the investigation, you will prepare your surface disinfectant, disposal jar and bacterial cultures. Then, you will pour the E. coli broth into the E coli soak dish and add the glass beads. Next, you will transfer the beads from the E coli soak dish to the E coli dry dish and then place 1 bead in each solution dish. You will incubate the beads for 10 minutes and then transfer them to the labeled broth tubes. Once you have prepared all 13 tubes, you will incubate the tubes for 48 hours. Finally, you will check for bacterial growth and determine the effectiveness of each antiseptic.

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).
Refer to your instructions and video on safe practices in the microbiology laboratory before beginning this investigation.
Isopropyl alcohol and Lysol<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> <button class='glossary-text'>disinfectant</button> are flammable. Keep containers away from any heat or flame sources.

Chlorine bleach, hydrogen peroxide, and Lysol<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> disinfectant are corrosive materials. Use these materials near a source of running water that can be used as a safety eye wash or safety shower if any corrosive material comes in contact with skin or eyes. Do not use bleach in an area without proper ventilation, such as an open window or a bathroom with a fan.
Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity.

Disinfect the work area with a 10% bleach solution (one part bleach to nine parts tap water) before starting the investigation. After completing your work, disinfect and discard any used inoculating tools and unneeded cultures. Disinfect the work area with a 10% bleach solution followed by soap and water. Always wear PPE when disinfecting.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

options.text: Sterilization kills microbes; sanitization cleans off microbes.
Sterilization kills microbes by heat; sanitization kills microbes by chemicals.
Sterilization inhibits microbial growth; sanitization kills microbes.
Sterilization cleans off microbes; sanitization inhibits microbial growth.
Sterilization kills microbes by chemicals; sanitization kills microbes by free radicals.

They give off noxious fumes and should only be used in a well-ventilated area.

typeBefore.text: Note: Use correct aseptic technique as you are working through this investigation. You may wish to review the Aseptic Technique and Use of Media investigation to refresh your memory. In particular, each time you remove the cap from a tube, the cap should be held, not placed on the work surface. The open mouth of each glass culture tube should be flamed as soon as the cap is removed and immediately before the cap is replaced. When you open the lid of a Petri dish, do not set it aside. Hold it over the dish to use as a shield to keep contaminating dust out.

Culture RecommendationsYou will need a relatively fresh broth culture of E. coli for this investigation to be successful.
  • If you need to reactivate a lyophilized culture, follow the package instructions using proper aseptic technique, and incubate until growth in the tryptic soy broth is apparent. You may wish to first review the video. Follow your instructor’s directions on whether to keep or discard your E. coli culture(s) at the end of the investigation.

pageData.text: Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water. Dry your hands, and then put on your PPE.
Disinfect the work surface, culture tube rack, and grease pencil or permanent marker with a 10% bleach solution.

Retrieve the needed media and, if applicable, lyophilized culture from storage. If the media have been stored in the refrigerator, allow them to sit for approximately 15 minutes to warm up to room temperature.
Prepare your disposal jar by filling it with 70% isopropyl alcohol.
Obtain the liquid paraffin candle from the equipment kit. Light the candle. Be sure to keep the candle a safe distance from the open container of isopropyl alcohol.

Mix the contents of the reactivated or older E. coli culture by tapping the tube or rolling it between your palms. Aseptically transfer a loop of broth to a fresh tube of 10 mL nutrient broth. Label the tube “E. coli.”
Place the loop in the disposal jar.
Extinguish the candle, and empty the alcohol from the disposal jar as described in the Disposal and Cleanup section. Keep the disposal jar for later use.
Incubate the inoculated broth tube upright in the rack with the cap slightly loose. E. coli will grow at room temperature but grows fastest at approximately 37° C (99° F).
Disinfect the work area with a 10% bleach solution, remove your PPE, and wash your hands thoroughly.
Allow between two and three days of incubation for the E. coli to grow. Do not proceed until the culture is growing well.
Obtain the listed materials from the investigation and equipment sets, the culture materials, and the materials listed as “needed but not supplied.”
Prepare to work as described in Steps 1–5.

In Activity 1, you will prepare solutions of various and at different concentrations in Petri dishes. You will then inoculate glass beads with E. coli, soak one bead in each solution, then inoculate tryptic soy broth tubes with the treated beads. The broth tubes will incubate for 48 hours before you observe them for microbial growth.

Take 3 Petri dishes, and use the grease pencil or permanent marker to label the outside of the lid of each as follows:
  • 1.0% bleach
  • 0.1% bleach
  • 0.01% bleach

Take the surface <button class='glossary-text'>disinfectant</button> (10% bleach solution), and use a transfer pipette to add 1 mL of the 10% bleach solution to the “1.0% bleach” Petri dish. Discard the pipette in the garbage.
Use a new transfer pipette to add 9 mL of distilled water to the “1.0% bleach” dish.
Carefully mix the solution in the “1.0% bleach” dish with the same transfer pipette that was used to add the water. Then discard the pipette.
Use a new transfer pipette to add 1 mL of the 1.0% bleach solution to the “0.1% bleach” dish. Discard the pipette.
Using a new transfer pipette, add 9 mL of distilled water to the “0.1% bleach” dish.
Carefully mix the solution in the “0.1% bleach” dish with the same transfer pipette that was used to add water. Discard the pipette.
Use a new transfer pipette to add 1 mL of the 0.1% bleach solution to the “0.01% bleach” dish. Discard the pipette.
Using a new transfer pipette, add 9 mL of distilled water to the “0.01% bleach” dish.
Mix the solution in the “0.01% bleach” dish with the same pipette that was used to add water. Discard the pipette.

typeBefore.title:
B
 Setting Up Lysol® Solutions (6 steps)

pageData.text:
Take 3 Petri dishes, and label the outside of the lid of each as follows:
  • 10% Lysol® solution
  • 5% Lysol® solution
  • 2.5% Lysol® solution

Using a new pipette, add 10 mL of Lysol® disinfectant to the “10% Lysol<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>” dish. Use the same pipette to add 5 mL of Lysol<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> disinfectant to the “5% Lysol®” dish and 2.5 mL of Lysol<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> disinfectant to the “2.5% Lysol<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>” dish. Discard the pipette.
Using a new transfer pipette, add 5 mL of distilled water to the “5% Lysol<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>” dish.
Mix the solution in the “5% Lysol<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>” dish with the same transfer pipette that was used to add water. Discard the pipette.
Using a new transfer pipette, add 7.5 mL of distilled water to the “2.5% Lysol<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>” dish.
Carefully mix the solution in the “2.5% Lysol<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>” dish with the same transfer pipette that was used to add water. Discard the pipette.

typeBefore.title:
C
 Setting Up Hydrogen Peroxide Solutions (8 steps)

pageData.text:
Take 3 Petri dishes, and label the outside of the lid of each as follows:
  • 3.0% hydrogen peroxide
  • 0.3% hydrogen peroxide
  • 0.03% hydrogen peroxide
Note: The commercial concentration of hydrogen peroxide is 3%.
Use a new transfer pipette to add 10 mL of the hydrogen peroxide solution to the “3.0% hydrogen peroxide” dish.
Use the same transfer pipette to add 1 mL of the 3.0% hydrogen peroxide solution to the “0.3% hydrogen peroxide” dish. Discard the pipette.
Using a new transfer pipette, add 9 mL of distilled water to the “0.3% hydrogen peroxide” dish.
Carefully mix the solution in the “0.3% hydrogen peroxide” dish with the same transfer pipette that was used to add water. Discard the pipette.
Use a new transfer pipette to add 1 mL of the 0.3% hydrogen peroxide solution to the “0.03% hydrogen peroxide” dish. Discard the pipette.
Using a new transfer pipette, add 9 mL of distilled water to the “0.03% hydrogen peroxide” dish.
Carefully mix the solution in the “0.03% hydrogen peroxide” tube with the same transfer pipette that was used to add water. Discard the pipette.

typeBefore.title:
D
 Setting Up Isopropyl Alcohol Solutions (8 steps)

pageData.text:
Take 3 Petri dishes, and label the outside of the lid of each as follows:
  • 50% isopropyl alcohol
  • 30% isopropyl alcohol
  • 10% isopropyl alcohol

Use a new transfer pipette to add 7 mL of the isopropyl alcohol to the “50% isopropyl alcohol” dish. Use the same pipette to add 4 mL of alcohol to the “30% isopropyl alcohol” dish and 1.5 mL of alcohol to the “10% isopropyl alcohol” dish. Discard the pipette.
Using a new transfer pipette, add 3 mL of distilled water to the “50% isopropyl alcohol” dish.
Carefully mix the solution in the “50% isopropyl alcohol” dish with the same transfer pipette that was used to add water. Discard the pipette.
Using a new transfer pipette, add 6 mL of distilled water to the “30% isopropyl alcohol” dish.
Carefully mix the solution in the “30% isopropyl alcohol” dish with the same transfer pipette that was used to add water. Discard the pipette.
Using a new transfer pipette, add 8.5 mL of distilled water to the “10% isopropyl alcohol” dish.
Carefully mix the solution in the “10% isopropyl alcohol” dish with the same pipette that was used to add water. Discard the pipette.

typeBefore.title:
E
 Setting Up the Control (2 steps)

pageData.text: Label the outside of the lid of a Petri dish “Control.”
Using a new transfer pipette, add 10 mL of distilled water to the “Control” dish. Discard the pipette.

Obtain two sterile Petri dishes, and label the outside of the lids as follows:
  • E. coli soak
  • E. coli dry
Take the metal forceps, and immerse the tips in the disposal jar of 70% isopropyl alcohol.
Move the forceps through the candle flame until the alcohol on them ignites.
Note: Because the alcohol on the forceps will catch on fire, hold the forceps away from you until the flame goes out.

Wait several seconds for the forceps to cool. Then use the forceps to place the piece of filter paper in the bottom of the “E. coli dry” dish. Try to touch only the edge of the filter paper and only with the forceps.

Take your E. coli culture, tighten the cap, and disperse the sediment by tapping the tube or rolling it between your palms. Make sure the contents are mixed thoroughly with a uniformly cloudy (turbid) look.
Open the tube of E. coli, and aseptically pour the contents into the “E. coli soak” Petri dish.
Dip the forceps into the alcohol, and flame them again.
After the forceps have had several seconds to cool, carefully place 13 glass beads into the “E. coli soak” dish.

Use the forceps to take the 13 glass beads out of the “E. coli soak” dish. Put the beads on the filter paper in the “E. coli dry” dish. Evenly spread out the beads, and ensure that they are positioned away from the edge of the filter paper.
Replace the metal forceps in the disposal jar.
Drop 1 glass bead each into the dishes containing bleach, Lysol<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> disinfectant, hydrogen peroxide, isopropyl alcohol, and water.
Let the beads soak in these treatments for 10 minutes.
While soaking the beads, label 13 tryptic soy broth tubes so that each treatment dish has a corresponding broth tube (1.0% bleach, 0.1% bleach, and so on).
Note: Because so many tubes will be used in this activity, keep the cardboard box in which the broth tubes arrived, and use it as an additional culture tube rack.
Flame the forceps, and allow several seconds for them to cool.

Use the forceps to take the beads out of the dishes containing bleach, Lysol<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> disinfectant, hydrogen peroxide, isopropyl alcohol, and water. Place each bead in a new tube containing tryptic soy broth. Be sure to dip the forceps into the disposal jar, flame, and cool before transferring each bead. When finished, dip the forceps, flame them, let them cool, and then set them aside.
Tighten the cap on each tube firmly, and tap or roll the tubes to mix their contents.
Put the tubes in the tube rack and tryptic soy broth tube box, and incubate for 48 hours. The caps should be slightly loose.
After 48 hours, remove all the tryptic soy broth tube from the incubation area and tighten their caps.
Tap or roll the tubes to suspend their contents.
Check for bacterial growth. This can be seen as turbidity as well as particles floating or suspended in the broth. Photograph the tryptic soy broth tube.
Mark the results in Data Table 1. Indicate abundant growth as +++, scant growth as +, and intermediate growth as ++. Indicate lack of growth as –.

Notice which <button class='glossary-text'>disinfectant</button> concentration worked best and which <button class='glossary-text'>antiseptic</button> concentration worked best. Was there a large difference between disinfectants and antiseptics?

text: Discard used pipettes wrapped in an opaque plastic bag in the garbage. Wear PPE while handling the pipettes.

pageData.text:
Put on PPE to pour used isopropyl alcohol from the disposal jar down the drain. Allow the faucet to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the alcohol.
Keep your broth culture of E. coli from the Preparation section unless otherwise directed by your instructor. Heed any additional directions from your instructor regarding which cultures to keep and which to discard.

To dispose of any cultures that will not be used again and the Petri dishes used for soaking, drying, or treating the E. coli, put on your PPE, ensure adequate ventilation, and fill a lidded plastic container large enough to hold all the tubes and Petri dishes with a 10% bleach solution. Other than the “Lysol® solution” plates, open each tube or plate while holding it submerged in the bleach solution. Allow the cultures to soak in the bleach for at least 24 hours.

Then, while wearing your PPE, pour the bleach down the drain with the faucet running. Let the faucet continue to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the bleach. Place the disinfected tubes and plates in an opaque plastic bag, and discard it in the garbage.

Let all 3 “Lysol® solution” Petri dishes stand for 24 more hours. While wearing PPE, pour the liquid contents down the drain and allow the faucet to run for at least 30 seconds. Do not pour Lysol® and bleach into the sink at the same time. Rinse the sink thoroughly between disposing of bleach and Lysol® solutions. Wrap the dishes in an opaque bag, and discard it in the garbage.

text: 1. After working with microbes, be sure to disinfect the work space with a 10% bleach solution, and then clean with soap and water. Wear PPE whenever you are disinfecting.

pageData.title: Data Table 1. Disinfectant and antiseptic concentrations and bacterial growth

text: Based on your results, which antimicrobial agent(s) best inhibited the growth of E. coli? What was the lowest effective concentration of the agent(s)?
What can you conclude from your results about the relative effectiveness of antiseptics versus disinfectants in preventing the growth of E. coli?

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Many rod-shaped bacteria undergoing sporulation.

A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. Before beginning the investigation, you will prepare your surface disinfectant, disposal jar and bacterial cultures. To begin, you will label your Petri dishes and prepare the disinfectant solutions in each dish. Then, you will prepare the control dish. Next, you will place filter paper in the E coli dry dish. Then, you will pour the E. coli broth into the E coli soak dish and add the glass beads. Next, you will transfer the beads from the E coli soak dish to the E coli dry dish and then place 1 bead in each solution dish. You will incubate the beads for 10 minutes and then transfer them to the labeled broth tubes. Once you have prepared all 13 tubes, you will incubate the tubes for 48 hours. Finally, you will check for bacterial growth and determine the effectiveness of each antiseptic.

data.title: Antiseptic
data.content: A substance that is used to reduce microbe levels on or in living tissues

data.title: Autoclaving
data.content: The process of heating to a very high temperature under pressure

data.title: Cytoplasm
data.content: The aqueous fluid with dissolved ions and proteins found within a cell

data.title: Denaturing
data.content: Destroy the characteristic properties of (a protein or other biological macromolecule) by heat, acidity, or other environmental condition

data.title: Disinfectant
data.content: A substance that is used to reduce the number of microbes

data.title: Dormancy
data.content: A reversible state of low metabolic activity that some microbes can enter when faced with unfavorable environmental conditions

data.title: Endospore
data.content: A resistant asexual spore that develops inside some bacteria cells

data.title: Sanitizing
data.content: The process of reducing microbial numbers by cleaning

data.title: Sporulation
data.content: The formation of a spore to survive environmental changes until conditions are ideal for growth

data.title: Sterilization
data.content: The process of removing or killing all life from a material or surface
